questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with a 2 cm ulcerative lesion located on the lateral border of the anterior portion of the tongue, closer to the tip . During surgical planning, which group of lymph nodes is the most likely initial site of lymphatic drainage for this lesion?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Level I Explanation: The tip and lateral border of the anterior tongue primarily drain into the Level I lymph nodes , particularly: Level Ia (submental nodes) for the tip of the tongue Level Ib (submandibular nodes) for the lateral anterior tongue These are the first-echelon nodes for lesions located anteriorly and laterally, especially those close to the tip. Carcinoma Tongue: Common causes Smoking Spirit Sepsis Superficial glossitis Syphilis Spices Sharp tooth Leukoplakia, erythroplakia Symptoms Painless ulcer/swelling Excessive salivation Dysphagia Restricted tongue movement Halitosis Voice Change: In tumors of the posterior tongue Diagnosis Wedge biopsy; FNAC of lymph nodes Laryngoscopy: To view posterior growth CT/MRI: Assess tumor extent Orthopantomogram Treatment Surgery: For tumors <1 cm or carcinoma in situ: Wide local excision, 1 cm margin clearance. For tumors 1-2 cm: Partial glossectomy with 2 cm margin. For tumors >2 cm: Hemiglossectomy removing anterior 2/3 of tongue on one side. Posterior third growth: Total glossectomy (Kocher's approach). Palpable mobile lymph nodes: Radical neck dissection (unilateral/bilateral). Mandible involvement: Hemimandibulectomy. Commando Operation: Combined procedures involving wide excision or hemiglossectomy, hemimandibulectomy, and radical neck dissection. Radiotherapy: Small primary tumor: Curative radiotherapy (Brachytherapy). Large primary tumor: Pre-operative radiotherapy to reduce tumor size. Advanced tumors/secondaries: Palliative external radiotherapy. Post-operative: Radiotherapy to reduce relapse risk. Posterior third tumor: Curative and palliative radiotherapy. Chemotherapy: Used post-operatively or for palliation. Price-Hill Regimen: Methotrexate, vincristine, adriamycin, bleomycin and mercaptopurine. Level II (Option B) is incorrect because although it receives drainage from posterior parts of the anterior tongue and floor of mouth, it is typically a secondary drainage site for more posterior or deeper lesions. Level III (Option C) is incorrect because these nodes receive secondary or tertiary drainage from the tongue and are involved in more

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents with metastatic adenocarcinoma, but the primary tumor site remains unidentified. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the workup to help locate the primary tumor?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) PET scan Explanation: Carcinoma of unknown primary origin (CUP) r efers to metastatic cancer where the primary tumor is not identified at initial presentation. The most appropriate next step to locate the primary tumor is imaging studies, among which a PET scan is particularly useful. Diagnostic Workup: Clinicopathologic diagnosis: Evaluation of family and personal history: Identifies potential primary sites and risk factors. Physical examination: H/o previous surgeries and lesions. Biopsy and pathology: Fine-needle aspiration or core biopsy. Light microscopy with hematoxylin-and-eosin staining identifies the cancer type. Immunohistochemical tests: Immunohistochemical markers: These are peroxidase-labeled antibodies against specific tumor antigens, and help determine the tumor lineage. For e.g.: PSA and thyroglobulin (prostate and thyroid cancers). Cytokeratin stains: CK 7 and CK 20 determine tumor origin. Serum Tumor Markers and Cytogenetics: Tumor markers: PSA (for adenocarcinoma with bone metastasis), beta-human chorionic gonadotropin, alpha-fetoprotein (for germ cell tumors). Cytogenetics: Occasionally used to rule out lymphoma. Imaging Studies: CT scan: Abdominal and pelvic CT to locate the primary tumor and evaluate the disease extent. Mammography: Recommended for women with metastatic adenocarcinoma. MRI: Effective for assessing isolated axillary lymph node metastases and suspected occult primary breast carcinoma. PET Scan: Useful in non-cervical carcinoma of unknown primary origin (CUP) to guide biopsy and assess disease extent. (Option B) Advanced Techniques: Gene expression profiling: Uses DNA microarrays and RT-PCR to predict tumor origin based on gene expression patterns. Complete blood count (Option A ): Helpful for general health assessment; it does not directly assist in locating the primary tumor. Start chemotherapy (Option B): Should not be initiated without identifying the primary tumor, as treatment decisions are based on the tumor’s origin and characteristics. Exploratory surgery (Option C): Not typically the first step; imaging studies are preferred to guide further diagnostic approaches.

questions.question: A 58-year-old patient who recently had a neck dissection is experiencing swelling, pain, and fluid accumulation in the surgical area. Which of the following is NOT a typical complication associated with neck dissection?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Facial nerve paralysis Explanation: Facial nerve paralysis is more associated with surgeries of the parotid gland rather than neck dissection. Complications of Neck dissection: Intraoperative Complications Postoperative Complication Hemorrhage Injury to nerves Accessory nerve injury (Option C) Marginal mandibular nerve injury Vagus nerve injury Hypoglossal nerve injury Phrenic nerve injury Sympathetic trunk injury Thoracic duct injury (Option B) Pneumothorax Salivary leakage Hemorrhage Deep dehiscence (Option A) Wound infection Cephalic vein stasis Bronchopneumonia Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, Edition 28, page no:848 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9442196/

questions.question: A patient undergoes a neck dissection that involves removing lymph nodes from levels I-V, while preserving the spinal accessory nerve, and internal jugular vein. What type of neck dissection was performed?

options.C: Modified Radical Neck Dissection Type II
options.D: Modified Radical Neck Dissection Type III

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Modified Radical Neck Dissection Type II Explanation: Type of Neck Dissection Nodes Removed Structures Preserved Comprehensive: Radical Neck Dissection (RND) (Option A) Level I - V None Bilateral Radical Neck Dissection Level I - V (both sides) - Modified Radical Neck Dissection Type I Level I - V SAN Modified Radical Neck Dissection Type II (Option C) Level I - V SAN, SCM Modified Radical Neck Dissection Type III (Option D) Level I - V SAN, SCM, IJV Selective Node Dissection: Supraomohyoid Neck Dissection Level I - III SAN, SCM, IJV Extended Supraomohyoid (Anterolateral Neck Dissection) (Option B) Level I - IV Posterolateral Neck Dissection Level II - V with suboccipital, retroauricular nodes Anterior/ Central Dissection Level VI SAN: Spinal accessory nerve; SCM: Sternocleidomastoid muscle; IJV: Internal jugular vein Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, Edition 28, page no:811 SRB’s Surgical Operations, Edition 1, page no:406

questions.question: A 58-year-old male is scheduled for a neck dissection due to metastatic squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity. Which incision will the surgeon choose to provide optimal access to all cervical lymph node levels?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Modified Schobinger incision Explanation: Modified Schobinger Incision is the most preferred incision for adequate access to all levels of the neck lymph nodes. Types of Incisions in Neck Dissection 1. Macfee Incision: Two horizontal parallel incisions. Provide the best scar cosmesis. Limited access to deeper structures. 2.Modified Macfee Incision: Improves access to all neck node levels and a narrow bridge, thus facilitating an easier dissection of the spinal accessory nerve. 3.Reversed Hockey Stick Incision: Long anterior skin flap, superior access to all five lymph node levels. Other incisions: Conley/Schecter incision Hayes Martin incision Triradiate incision Apron incision Fischel T-J incision Macfee incision (Option A) is cosmetically favorable but has limited access to deeper structures, which can compromise disease clearance in extensive cases. Y-shaped incision (Option C) is historically significant and provides broad access. However, it is less commonly used today due to less favorable cosmetic outcomes Modified Macfee Incision (Option D): While it offers better access than the original Macfee Incision, it may still be less optimal compared to the Modified Schobinger Incision for comprehensive exposure.

questions.question: A 60-year-old female diagnosed with oral cavity cancer presents with a non-healing ulcer on her lower lip. Which of the following lymph node levels is most likely involved in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Levels I, II and III Explanation: Levels of lymph nodes of neck: Levels Lymph nodes Boundaries Associated primary malignancy I Ia: Submental Anterior belly of digastric muscle, hyoid bone, midline, mandible. Floor of mouth, Anterior tongue, Mandibular alveolar ridge, Lower lip (Option C) Ib: Submandibular nodes Anterior and posterior bellies of digastric muscle, inferior border of mandible. Oral cavity (Option C) Anterior nasal cavity Mid-face soft tissues Submandibular gland II Upper jugular group Skull base, horizontal plane extending from hyoid bone and sternocleidomastoid. IIa: Anterior to the spinal accessory nerve. IIb: Posterior to the spinal accessory nerve. Nasal and oral cavities, (Option C) Nasopharynx Oropharynx Hypopharynx Larynx, (Option B) Major salivary glands. III Middle jugular group Strap muscles, sternocleidomastoid, horizontal plane from inferior border of cricoid cartilage. Oral cavity Nasopharynx Oropharynx Hypopharynx Larynx (Option B) IV Lower jugular group Strap muscles, sternocleidomastoid, and clavicle. Hypopharynx Oropharynx Larynx (Option B) Thyroid gland (Option A) Cervical esophagus V Posterior triangle group Va: Lateral to SCM muscle, inferior and medial to splenius capitis and trapezius, superior to the spinal accessory nerve. Nasopharynx Oropharynx Thyroid gland (Option A) Vb: Lateral to SCM muscle, medial to trapezius, inferior to the spinal accessory nerve, superior to the clavicle. VI Anterior compartment group Hyoid bone, suprasternal notch, lateral extent of the strap muscles bilaterally. Lower lip Soft tissues of the chin VII Superior mediastinal nodes Inferior to the suprasternal notch in the upper mediastinum. Nasopharynx Pharyngeal wall Oropharynx (Option D)

questions.question: A 35-year-old male presents with a smooth, tender swelling in the right lower jaw in relation to tooth caries. A panoramic radiograph shows a well-defined radiolucency around the roots of the lower right first molar. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Dental cyst Explanation: Feature Ameloblastoma (Option C) Dentigerous Cyst (Option A) Dental Cyst (Option B) Description Arises from dental epithelium, probably from the enamel/ dental lamina. Occurs commonly in the mandible or maxilla, occasionally in the skull base Locally malignant tumor Unilocular cystic swelling arising to the dental epithelium from an unerupted tooth. Common in the lower jaw but can also occur in the upper jaw. Occurs over the crown of an unerupted tooth; commonly seen in relation to premolars or molars. Occurs under the root of a chronically infected dead erupted tooth. Clinical Features Painless, Progressively enlarging swelling in the jaw (usually mandible), Smooth and hard, with an intact inner table. Painless, Smooth, hard swelling over the crown of an unerupted tooth, Causes expansion of the outer table of the mandible. Smooth, tender swelling in the jaw related to a caries tooth, Causes expansion of the jaw bone. Investigations Orthopantomogram (OPG): Honeycomb appearance CT scan Biopsy Orthopantomogram (OPG): Tooth within the cyst, which is well defined. Dental Specialty Group, Jbarta" data-hash="" data-license="CC-BY-3.0" data-source="https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:JawCyst_(with_arrows).jpg" data-tags="" height="81" src="https://image.prepladder.com/content/TNVKNTKgdKSF0DBoUa051739248026.png" width="200" /> Orthopantomogram (OPG): Circular radiolucent area in relation to the root of a normally erupted tooth. Treatment Segmental resection of mandible or hemimandibulectomy with reconstruction of the mandible. Small cyst: Excision of the cyst. Large cysts: Initial marsupialization followed by excision. Extraction of unerupted tooth. Antibiotics, Drainage or excision of the cyst with extraction of the infected tooth. Epulis (Option D) is swelling arising from the mucoperiosteum of gums (gingiva).

questions.question: A 55-year-old male presents with a large tumor involving the floor of the maxillary sinus, causing facial swelling and nasal obstruction. During surgery, the surgical team uses the approach shown in the image. Identify the type of incision used in this procedure.
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Weber-Fergusson Incision Explanation: Maxillary Sinus Carcinoma Origin: Arises from sinus lining, often silent and mistaken for sinusitis. Spread: Destroys maxillary sinus, invading nearby structures. Clinical Features: Common in: 40-60 years, more males. Early Signs: Nasal stuffiness, bloodstained discharge, facial pain. Late Signs: Depend on spread and severity. Spread: Direct, lymphatic or hematogenous. Diagnosis: Radiograph: Shows sinus opacity and bone destruction. CT Scan: Best for staging and extent. Biopsy: Taken from the nose or mouth. Ohngren's classification: An imaginary plane from the medial canthus of the eye to

questions.question: A 55-year-old male patient requires mandibular reconstruction following the resection of a tumor. The surgeon is considering different bone graft options. Which of the following bone grafts is not likely to be chosen for bony reconstruction of the mandible?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Tibia bone graft Explanation: Mandibular Reconstruction: Gold Standard Flap Reconstruction with composite free flaps is considered the gold standard for segmental mandibular defects. Choice of Flap Depends on defect site, size, complexity, patient comorbidities, and surgeon’s training and preference. Anterior Defect More challenging to reconstruct than posterior defects; crucial for achieving satisfactory function. Graft used (Options A, B & D) Fibula Iliac crest Scapula Radius Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, Edition 28, page no: 825 https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK563241/

questions.question: A patient is scheduled for segmental mandibulectomy due to a lower alveolar tumor invading the mandible. Which statement accurately describes this procedure?

options.B: Suitable for tumors not invading the mandible.
options.C: Removes the entire height of the mandible.
options.D: Resection of partial thickness of the mandible.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Removes the entire height of the mandible. Explanation: Feature Segmental Mandibulectomy Marginal Mandibulectomy Definition Removal of the full height of the invaded section of the mandible. (Option C) Removal of a partial thickness of the mandible. (Option D) Continuity of mandible Loss of continuity of the lower border. Continuity of the lower border remains intact. (Option A) Indication Tumor invading the mandible, often through the dental root leading into the mandibular canal and cancellous bone. Tumor is close to the mandible but does not invade it. (Option B) Image

questions.question: A 65-year-old male with lower alveolar squamous cell carcinoma presents with an ulcerated mass, extensive cortical bone erosion, invasion beyond the inferior alveolar canal, and palpable submandibular lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate treatment?

options.D: Marginal resection, along with block dissection

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Segmental mandibulectomy Explanation: If there is more than superficial cortical erosion of the mandible, the marrow space is at risk of harboring malignancy and thus, segmental mandibulectomy is required for adequate margin control. Lower Alveolar Cancer: Mostly seen in men. Squamous cell carcinoma(SCC) is the most common malignancy of the lower alveolus. Tumor Spread: Can extend to the cheek, floor of the mouth, retromolar trigone, or hard palate. May invade underlying bone and spread rapidly along the neurovascular bundle. Nodal metastases commonly occur in submandibular and upper jugular nodes. Surgery: Preferred treatment method. Early Lesions (tumors adherent to periosteum): Treated by local excision with marginal resection of the mandible. Extensive Lesions (bone invasion present): Require wide excision, potentially involving segmental or hemimandibulectomy. Nodal Involvement: Block dissection may be performed if nodes are palpable. Radiotherapy (Option A) is avoided due to the risk of radio-osteonecrosis and limited effectiveness for extensive bone involvement. Local excision with marginal resection (Option B) is inadequate for advanced tumors with extensive bone erosion and invasion beyond the inferior alveolar canal. Marginal resection along with block dissection (Option D) does not fully address extensive bone invasion.

questions.question: A patient presents with 2.5 cm ulceroproliferative adenoid cystic carcinoma on the left side of the hard palate. Imaging shows no evidence of bone invasion or lymph node involvement. Which of the following is the most appropriate management strategy?

options.A: Wide local excision with frozen section control
options.B: Partial maxillectomy with ipsilateral neck dissection

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Partial maxillectomy without neck dissection Explanation: For an adenoid cystic carcinoma of the hard palate, partial maxillectomy is the appropriate surgical approach to ensure adequate margins. Despite the absence of clinical bone invasion, microscopic invasion is common in these tumors. Elective neck dissection is generally not performed for adenoid cystic carcinomas of the hard palate due to their low propensity for lymphatic spread. Carcinoma of the Hard Palate Salivary gland tumors in the palate are often malignant, with adenoid cystic carcinoma being common. Adenoid cystic carcinoma : Present as a single, solid, smooth swelling with an ulcer on the summit. Squamous cell carcinoma : Characterized by an ulcer with raised and everted edges. Upper deep cervical lymph nodes are involved in 25% of cases. Malignant tumors can invade the periosteum, bone, maxilla, sinus, or nose. Risk factor Reverse smokers have higher risk of squamous cell carcinoma due to repeated thermal injury from smoking rolled tobacco (Churat). Investigations Wedge biopsy FNAC lymph node CT Scan: To check for tumor extensions. Treatment Wide excision with removal of the underlying palatal bone. Maxillectomy: Partial or total, often done using the Weber-Ferguson incision . Reconstruction: With a myocutaneous flap and dental prosthesis. Postoperative radiotherapy and neck block dissection are often required. Wide local excision with frozen section control (Option A): While wide local excision might be considered for very small, superficial lesions, a 2.5 cm adenoid cystic carcinoma of the hard palate typically requires more extensive resection to ensure clear margins and address potential bone involvement. Partial maxillectomy with ipsilateral neck dissection (Option B): Although partial maxillectomy is correct, routine elective neck dissection is not typically performed for adenoid cystic carcinomas of the hard palate unless there is clinical or radiological evidence of nodal involvement. Radiotherapy alone (Option D) is not the standard first-line treatment for resectable adenoid cystic carcinomas of the hard palate. Surgery is generally preferred, with radiotherapy often used as adjuvant treatment. Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Pages: 780, 791 SRB’s Manual of Surgery, Edition 6, page no: 388,389

questions.question: A female who chews betel quid has pale, fibrous oral mucosa and a 2 cm interincisal opening. Biopsy revealed increased collagen deposition in the lamina propria. Which of the following is the most likely complication of this condition if left untreated?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Malignant transformation Explanation: The patient's presentation is consistent with oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF). The most significant long-term complication of untreated OSMF is malignant transformation. Oral submucous fibrosis is considered a potentially malignant disorder due to its significant risk of progressing to oral squamous cell carcinoma. Regular follow-up and screening of OSMF patients are crucial for the early detection of any malignant changes. Management should focus on habit cessation, nutritional support, and addressing fibrosis to potentially reduce the risk of malignant transformation. Carcinoma Buccal Mucosa: Precipitating Factors Smoking Spirit Syphilis Sharp tooth Sepsis Spices Betel Nut Chewing Premalignant Lesions Leukoplakia Oral submucous fibrosis Erythroplakia Sideropenic dysphagia Chronic hyperplastic candidiasis Syphilitic glossitis Clinical Features Painless ulcer in cheek initially Pain: Develops when the ulcer involves skin, bone, or becomes secondarily infected Halitosis Retromolar trigone involvement: Indicates advanced disease Trismus and dysphagia Fungating lesion: Tumor breaking through the skin Investigations Wedge Biopsy: Taken from the edge of the ulcer FNAC: For lymph node assessment CT/MRI: To assess tumor extent Orthopantomogram (OPG): Assess mandibular involvement Management Surgery: Wide excision: Removal of the tumor with a 1-2 cm margin. Hemimandibulectomy: Performed when the tumor involves the mandible. Neck lymph node dissection: Radical or modified radical dissection depending on lymph node involvement. Radiotherapy: Curative or palliative: Brachytherapy or external radiotherapy. Pre-op radiotherapy: Given to shrink fixed lymph nodes, making them operable. Post-op radiotherapy: For T3/T4 tumors or N2/N3 nodal status to reduce recurrence. Chemotherapy: Pre-operative to downstage tumors. Post-operative to improve outcomes. Chemoradiotherapy for unresectable tumors. Drugs Used: Methotrexate, cisplatin, vincristine, bleomycin, adriamycin. Candidiasis (Option A): While oral candidiasis can occur in OSMF patients due to an altered oral environment, it is not considered a major complication of untreated OSMF. Bilateral submandibular gland hypertrophy (Option C) is not a typical complication of OSMF. In fact, OSMF may lead to atrophy of salivary glands rather than hypertrophy. Spontaneous remission of fibrosis (Option D): OSMF is a progressive condition and does not undergo spontaneous remission. Without intervention, the fibrosis typically worsens over time.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the extent of the oral cavity is false?

options.A: The anterior border of the oral cavity begins at the vermillion border.
options.B: Superiorly, the oral cavity includes the soft palate up to the uvula.
options.C: The posterior extent of the oral cavity ends at the circumvallate papillae of the tongue.
options.D: The tonsils are not a part of the oral cavity.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Superiorly, the oral cavity includes the soft palate up to the uvula. Explanation: The soft palate is a part of the oropharynx and is not included in the oral cavity. The extent of the oral cavity is as follows: Anteriorly, it starts from the vermillion border of the lip (Option A) . Superiorly, it extends up to the junction of hard palate and soft palate. It extends postero - inferiorly up to the junction of the anterior 2/3rd and the posterior 1/3rd of the tongue, i.e., till the circumvallate papillae (Option C) . And laterally till the anterior tonsillar pillars . The tonsils , uvula, and soft palate are part of the oropharynx, which shows different characteristics from the oral cavity. The oral cavity has 8 subsites according to the specific etiological, pathological, prognostic, and treatment-related peculiarities: The mucosal lip The mandibular alveolus Floor of mouth Anterior 2/3rd of the tongue (mobile tongue) Buccal mucosa Retromandibular trigone Maxillary alveolus Hard palate Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, pg: 813. Schwartz Principles of Surgery, 11th edition, pg: 630.

questions.question: A 65-year-old patient presents with a 2.5 cm ulcerative lesion on the right side of his lower lip confirmed as squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the primary lymphatic drainage and surgical management of this lesion?

options.A: Drains to submental nodes; level I neck dissection is sufficient.
options.B: Drains to ipsilateral submandibular nodes; levels I-III neck dissection is recommended.
options.C: High risk of contralateral metastasis; bilateral neck dissection is needed.
options.D: Drains to preauricular and parotid nodes; requires superficial parotidectomy.

questions.explanation: recommended. Correct Answer: B) Drains to ipsilateral submandibular nodes; levels I-III neck dissection is recommended. Explanation: The lymphatic drainage of the lower lip is primarily to the submental (level IA) and submandibular (level IB) nodes . There's a significant risk of occult nodal metastasis for a lesion of this size, especially one close to the commissure. Therefore, a selective neck dissection, including levels I-III on the ipsilateral side, is typically recommended even in N0. Drains to submental nodes; level I neck dissection is sufficient (Option A): While the submental nodes are involved in lower lip drainage, they are not the sole primary site. Moreover, dissection of level I alone would be inadequate for a lesion of this size High risk of contralateral metastasis; bilateral neck dissection is needed (Option C): Lower lip lesions can occasionally metastasize to contralateral nodes, especially when close to the midline. A lesion on the right side extending to the commissure doesn't typically warrant bilateral neck dissection unless there's clinical or radiological evidence of contralateral spread. Drains to preauricular and parotid nodes; requires superficial parotidectomy (Option D): This pattern of drainage is more typical for upper lip or cheek lesions. Carcinoma Lip Common Causes UV radiation exposure Tobacco use Chronic irritation (e.g., ill-fitting dentures) Immunosuppression Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection Chronic inflammatory conditions (e.g., actinic cheilitis) Clinical Features Non-healing progressive painless ulcer Everted edge with indurations Growth moves with the lip Submental, submandibular and upper deep neck nodes may get enlarged. Tender firm lymph nodes may be due to infection; hard initially non-tender nodes are due to carcinoma spread. Fungation, bleeding, halitosis. Diagnosis Wedge biopsy FNAC of lymph nodes CT/MRI head and neck Management Early Stage (T1-T2N0): Wide local excision with 1 cm margins Consider elective neck dissection for tumors >2 cm or >4 mm depth Reconstruction: Primary closure, local flaps, or skin grafts Advanced Stage (T3-T4 or N+): Wide local excision with ≥ 1 cm margins Neck dissection (comprehensive or selective based on nodal status) Complex reconstruction (local/regional flaps, free tissue transfer) Adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy based on pathological findings Management of the Neck: Elective neck dissection for high-risk tumors (>2 cm, >4 mm depth) Therapeutic neck dissection for clinically positive nodes Levels typically addressed: I-III for N0 neck, I-V for N+ neck

questions.question: A 72-year-old farmer presents with a 3.5 cm exophytic lesion on his lower lip. Biopsy confirms well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with 8 mm depth of invasion. There are no palpable lymph nodes. Which of the following is the correct management strategy?

options.A: Wide local excision with 5 mm margins and neck observation.
options.B: Wide local excision with 1 cm margins and ipsilateral neck dissection.
options.C: Wide local excision with 1 cm margins and bilateral neck dissection.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Wide local excision with 1 cm margins and ipsilateral neck dissection. ≤ 4 cm) with >5 mm depth of invasion, wide local excision with at least 1 cm margins is recommended. Ipsilateral selective neck dissection (levels I-III) is appropriate for unilateral lesions not crossing the midline. Wide local excision with 1 cm margins and bilateral neck dissection (Option C): Bilateral neck dissection is not routinely indicated for unilateral lip lesions unless they cross the midline or approach the oral commissure. Radiotherapy alone (Option D) is not the standard first-line treatment for resectable lip carcinomas of this size. Surgery offers better local control and allows for pathological staging of the neck. TNM Staging of Carcinoma lip: T Stage : Tis: Carcinoma in situ T1 : Tumor ≤ 2 cm and ≤ 5 mm depth of invasion T2 : Tumor ≤ 2 cm and >5 mm but ≤ 10 mm depth, OR Tumor >2 cm but ≤ 4 cm and ≤ 10 mm depth T3 : Tumor >4 cm OR any tumor >10 mm depth of invasion T4 : Invasion of adjacent structures N Stage: N0: No regional lymph node metastasis N1-N3 : Based on number, size, and laterality of involved nodes M Stage: M0: No distant metastasis M1: Distant metastasis Management of Carcinoma lip: Early Stage (T1-T2N0) Wide local excision with 1 cm margins Consider elective neck dissection for tumors >2 cm or >4 mm depth Reconstruction: Primary closure, local flaps, or skin grafts Advanced Stage (T3-T4 or N+) Wide local excision with ≥ 1 cm margins Neck dissection (comprehensive or selective based on nodal status) Complex reconstruction (local/regional flaps, free tissue transfer) Adjuvant radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy based on pathological findings Reconstruction Options Wedge excision and primary closure (for small lesions) Local flaps: Abbe-Estlander, Karapandzic, nasolabial Regional flaps: Forehead, cervicofacial Free tissue transfer: Radial forearm free flap, anterolateral thigh flap Management of the Neck Elective neck dissection for high-risk tumors (>2 cm, >4 mm depth) Therapeutic neck dissection for clinically positive nodes Levels typically addressed: I-III for N0 neck, I-V for N+ neck Radiotherapy Adjuvant: For positive margins, perineural invasion, multiple positive nodes Definitive: For patients unfit for surgery or refusing surgery Brachytherapy: Can be considered for select early-stage lesions Chemotherapy Not routinely used in early-stage disease May be combined with radiotherapy in locally advanced cases Follow-up and Surveillance Regular follow-up visits: Every 1-3 months for the first year, then gradually decreasing frequency

questions.question: A 62-year-old male with recurrent squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity is being considered for immunotherapy using pembrolizumab. Which of the following correctly describes the mechanism of action of the drug?

options.A: Inhibits VEGF to prevent tumor angiogenesis
options.B: Blocks PD-1 receptor, enhancing T-cell anti-tumor activity
options.C: Targets EGFR to inhibit tumor cell proliferation
options.D: Activates NK cells to induce antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Blocks PD-1 receptor, enhancing T-cell anti-tumor activity Explanation: Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the programmed cell death-1 (PD-1) receptor. By blocking PD-1, it prevents the interaction between PD-1 and its ligands (PD-L1 and PD-L2). This blockade enhances T-cell function and anti-tumor immune responses. In oral cavity cancers, this leads to improved tumor cell recognition and destruction by the immune system. Inhibiting VEGF to prevent tumor angiogenesis (Option A) is the mechanism of action for drugs like bevacizumab. Targeting EGFR to inhibit tumor cell proliferation (Option C) describes the mechanism of action for cetuximab. Activating NK cells to induce antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity (Option D) is more closely associated with drugs like cetuximab, which can induce ADCC. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, 830.

questions.question: A 59-year-old male with T2N2bM0 squamous cell carcinoma of the buccal mucosa underwent surgery. The postoperative histopathology report reveals close surgical margin (< 5 mm) and extracapsular extension in two lymph nodes. What is the most appropriate adjuvant treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Concurrent chemoradiotherapy Explanation: Concurrent chemoradiotherapy is the most appropriate adjuvant treatment for this patient due to the presence of high-risk features: close surgical margins and extracapsular extension (ECE) in lymph nodes. In this case, the close margin and ECE in multiple nodes warrant the addition of chemotherapy to radiotherapy to improve locoregional control and overall survival. Radiotherapy alone (Option A) is insufficient for high-risk features like ECE. Chemotherapy alone (Option B) is not a standard practice as adjuvant therapy in oral cavity cancer. Observation and close follow-up (Option D) is inappropriate, given the high-risk features present. Adjuvant Therapy in Oral Cavity Cancer: Adjuvant therapy refers to additional treatment given after primary treatment (usually surgery) to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence. In oral cavity cancer, it typically involves radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or a combination of both. Indications for Adjuvant Therapy: Therapy Indications Radiotherapy alone Intermediate risk features: T3 or T4a primary tumors N2 or N3 nodal disease (without extracapsular extension) Perineural invasion Lymphovascular invasion Single node >3 cm or multiple positive nodes Close margins (between 5mm and 1cm) Concurrent chemoradiotherapy High-risk features: Positive surgical margins Extracapsular extension of nodal disease T4b tumors N3 nodal disease Multiple positive nodes with extracapsular extension Specific indications pT3 or pT4 primary tumors N2 or N3 neck disease Perineural invasion Vascular embolism Lymphatic invasion Considerations for chemotherapy addition Age <70 years Good performance status No significant comorbidities Adjuvant therapy is decided based on pathological findings after surgery. It aims to improve locoregional control and overall survival. The most common chemotherapy agent used is cisplatin. Radiotherapy is typically started within 6 weeks of surgery. Treatment decisions should be made in a multidisciplinary setting. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Page 829.

questions.question: A 58-year-old male with a 6 cm x 4 cm defect involving more than 50% of the tongue after excision for a T3N1M0 squamous cell carcinoma needs reconstruction. Which of the following flaps would be most appropriate for reconstruction for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Radial forearm free flap Explanation: The radial forearm free flap (RFFF) is the most appropriate choice for reconstructing this oral cavity defect involving a significant portion of the mobile tongue. In this case, where more than 50% of the mobile tongue is involved, the RFFF would provide the best functional outcome in terms of speech and swallowing. The RFFF is considered the gold standard for tongue reconstruction due to its: Thin and pliable nature, allowing for better mobility and articulation Long vascular pedicle, facilitating easier anastomosis Large surface area that can be harvested Minimal bulk, which is crucial for preserving tongue function Ability to provide sensate reconstruction if needed Flaps Used for Reconstruction in Oral Cavity Cancer: The goal of reconstruction is to restore form and function, including speech, swallowing, and aesthetics. The choice of flap should balance the needs of the defect with donor site morbidity and the patient's overall condition. 1. Radial Forearm Free Flap (RFFF): Ideal for tongue, floor of mouth, buccal mucosa Thin, pliable, with long pedicle Potential for sensate reconstruction 2. Anterolateral Thigh (ALT) Free Flap (Option B): Versatile for larger defects of the mandible, floor of mouth, or pharynx, especially in patients who are poor candidates for free flap surgery. Can be thinned for intraoral use. Minimal donor site morbidity 3. Fibula Free Flap: Gold standard for mandibular reconstruction. Can provide bone, muscle, and skin. 4. Pectoralis Major Myocutaneous Flap (Option C): Workhorse pedicled flap for head and neck. Useful for salvage cases or when free flaps are contraindicated. Harvesting a pectoralis major myocutaneous flap based on the thoracoacromial artery (blue arrow), skin paddle (outlined in blue), and muscle flap (outlined in green). B, The flap was rotated 180 degrees and used to cover the neck wound. 5. Submental Island Flap: Regional flap for small to medium intraoral defects. Good color match for facial skin. 6. Temporalis Muscle Flap: For palate and maxillary defects. Proximity to defect site. Supraclavicular artery island flap (Option D) is a regional flap that, while useful for some head and neck reconstructions, lacks the pliability and thinness required for optimal tongue reconstruction. It's more suitable for cutaneous defects of the face and neck.

questions.question: A 62-year-old male presents with a T2N1M0 squamous cell carcinoma of the lateral border of the tongue. According to the latest National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines, what is the most appropriate initial management for this patient?

options.A: Wide local excision of the primary tumor only.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Surgery followed by adjuvant radiotherapy Explanation: According to the AJCC classification, T2N1M0 squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue is Stage III . The correct treatment for this T2N1M0 with Stage III squamous cell carcinoma of the tongue is surgery followed by adjuvant radiotherapy. For T2N1M0 oral cavity cancers, the standard of care is surgical resection of the primary tumor with appropriate margins, along with neck dissection for the clinically positive lymph nodes. Adjuvant radiotherapy is typically recommended for patients with intermediate to high-risk features, which include positive lymph nodes. Preservation of radiotherapy as an adjuvant treatment, which can address microscopic disease and reduce the risk of locoregional recurrence. Multidisciplinary approach for oral cancer: Stage Treatment Early-stage (I-II) Surgery is the mainstay of treatment. Radiotherapy can be an alternative in select cases. Locally advanced (III-IVA/B) Resectable: Surgery followed by adjuvant therapy (radiotherapy or chemoradiotherapy) based on pathological risk factors. Unresectable: Concurrent chemoradiotherapy or radiotherapy alone for patients unfit for chemotherapy. Metastatic (IVC) Palliative chemotherapy, immunotherapy, or best supportive care. Surgical management: Wide local excision with 1-1.5 cm margins Neck dissection for clinically node-positive disease and elective neck dissection for high-risk node-negative disease Reconstruction to optimize functional and aesthetic outcomes. Adjuvant Therapy in Oral Cavity Cancer: Adjuvant therapy refers to additional treatment given after primary treatment (usually surgery) to reduce the risk of cancer recurrence. In oral cavity cancer, it typically involves radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or a combination of both. Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 829, 830.

questions.question: A male presents with a painful 2.5 cm ulceroproliferative growth on the right lateral border of the tongue with induration extending to the floor of the mouth and a single, firm, mobile 1.5 cm lymph node palpable in the right submandibular region. The CT scan shows no mandible or extrinsic muscle involvement. What is the correct TNM staging for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) T3N1M0 Explanation: The correct staging for this patient's oral cavity cancer is T3N1M0. T3: Tumor >4 cm; or any tumor >10 mm depth of invasion. In this case, although the visible lesion is 2.5 cm, the induration extends to the floor of the mouth, making it a T3 lesion. N1: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, ≤ 3 cm in greatest dimension, extranodal extension (ENE) -ve. The patient has a single 1.5 cm lymph node in the ipsilateral submandibular region. M0: No distant metastasis. Investigations and Workup: Clinical examination Biopsy for histopathological confirmation Imaging studies: CT scan or MRI for local extent Chest X-ray for metastasis screening PET-CT for detecting occult primary tumors or distant metastases Ultrasonography of the neck for lymph node evaluation Dental evaluation and panoramic radiographs Staging of Oral Cavity Cancer (AJCC 8th Edition): T (Primary Tumor): Tx: Primary tumor cannot be assessed. Tis: Carcinoma in situ. T1: Tumor ≤ 2 cm, ≤ 5 mm depth of invasion (DOI). T2: Tumor ≤ 2 cm, DOI >5 mm and ≤ 10 mm; or tumor >2 cm but ≤ 4 cm, and ≤ 10 mm DOI. T3: Tumor >4 cm; or any tumor >10 mm DOI. T4a: Moderately advanced local disease - Invades through cortical bone, deep/ extrinsic muscle of tongue, maxillary sinus, or skin of the face. T4b: Very advanced local disease - Invades masticator space, pterygoid plates, skull base, or encases internal carotid artery. N (Regional Lymph Nodes): Nx: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. N0: No regional lymph node metastasis. N1: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral lymph node, ≤ 3 cm in greatest dimension. N2: N2a: Metastasis in a single ipsilateral node, >3 cm but ≤ 6 cm in greatest dimension. N2b: Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral nodes, all ≤ 6 cm). N2c: Metastasis in bilateral or contralateral lymph nodes, all ≤ 6 cm. N3: N3a: Metastasis in a lymph node >6 cm in greatest dimension, ENE(-). N3b: Metastasis in any node(s) with clinically overt ENE(+). M (Distant Metastasis): M0: No distant metastasis M1: Distant metastasis Stage Grouping: Stage 0 Tis N0 M0 Stage I T1 N0 M0 Stage II T2 N0 M0 Stage III T3 N0 M0 or T1-3 N1 M0 Stage IVA T4a N0-1 M0 or T1-4a N2 M0 Stage IVB Any T N3 M0 or T4b Any N M0 Stage IVC Any T Any N M1 Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Pages 816, 817.

questions.question: A 55-year-old patient presents with a non-healing ulcer in the oral cavity and is diagnosed with carcinoma oral cavity. Which of the following statements regarding carcinoma oral cavity is most accurate?

options.B: Ulcer lasting over 2 weeks is significant.
options.C: Adenocarcinoma is the most common oral cancer.
options.D: Oral carcinoma is the least common among head and neck tumors.

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Ulcer lasting over 2 weeks is significant. Explanation: Clinical features of oral carcinoma: Signs Symptoms Non-healing ulcer (>2 weeks duration) (Option B) Persistent neck swelling/ lymphadenopathy Pigmented lesion with a progressive increase in size Lesion with associated induration Soft-tissue lesion with associated radiographic changes Unexplained tooth mobility Sensory nerve deficit Chronic otalgia Trismus of unknown etiology Dysphagia Sore tongue Metastasis : HPV-negative cervical node metastasis has a bad prognosis. Most metastases occur in Level I and Level II on neck lymph nodes. Distant metastasis is rare (Option A) Adenocarcinoma is the most common oral cancer (Option C): The most common cancer of the oral cavity is squamous cell carcinoma, not adenocarcinoma. Oral carcinoma is the least common among head and neck tumors (Option D): Oral carcinoma is the most common head and neck tumor. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, pg: 818. Sabiston’s principles of surgery, 21st edition, pg: 778. SRB’s textbook of surgery, 6th edition, pg: 363.

questions.question: A patient who had developed a buccal squamous cell carcinoma was treated by complete resection and radiation therapy. After his treatment was completed and he had clear margins after the resection, he developed a new tumor in his oral cavity on his tongue. What is the basis of this development of a second primary tumor?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) All of the above Explanation: Field cancerization, field defect, or field effect refers to the condition in which a particular site is completely exposed to carcinogens often and hence has a tendency to develop a malignancy entirely or at multiple sites instead of at just one focal point. This explains the recurrence of tumors and the development of second primary tumors after the removal of the first, particularly in the oral cavity. Field cancerization is a process of transforming a precancerous lesion into a cancerous one. Prolonged exposure to carcinogens like tobacco and alcohol in the oral cavity leads to widespread epithelial changes, resulting in multifocal carcinoma. Criteria for a second primary to be due to field cancerization: The neoplasm must be distinct and anatomically separate (dysplastic mucosa around a tumor depicts a multicentric primary neoplasm and not a new primary tumor). A potential second primary due to metastasis or local relapse must be excluded ( tumor after 3 years of first diagnosis or new tumor at least 2cm of normal epithelium away from the first one). Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4419611/

questions.question: A 45-year-old female comes to the clinic with a reddish patch on her tongue, as shown in the figure. She gives a history of chewing pan masala for more than 15 years. She has no difficulty in opening her mouth and has no other comorbidities. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Erythroplakia Explanation: The condition here is erythroplakia. Erythroplakia is a bright red velvety plaque that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. Has a higher malignant potential than leukoplakia. Types : Homogenous Speckled Granular Erythroplakia interspersed with leukoplakia Management : Biopsy for diagnosis Surgical excision Strict follow-up Oral submucosal fibrosis(Option A) is a progressive fibrosis deep in the mucosa of the oral cavity. Causes trismus and ankylosing glossitis Common in Asians Males and females are equally affected. Cause : Hypersensitivity to tobacco, betel nut, chilli , areca nut, vitamin deficiencies, localised collagen disorders. Leads to alteration of collagen metabolism causing juxtaepithelial progressive inflammatory fibrosis of the submucosa. This leads to atrophy and dysplasia. Clinical features: Soreness in the mouth more during meals Burning, also more while eating Vesicular eruptions Trismus Difficulty in protruding tongue Fibrosis and scarring Management : Cessation of causative factors(tobacco, chilli, areca nut) Oral hygiene Dexamethasone local injections Hydrocortisone HCG submucosal injection Vitamin and iron supplementation Surgical excision with graft Stem cell therapy Plummer-Vinson syndrome (Option C) is seen in patients with chronic iron deficiency anemia. questions.question: A 50-year-old patient comes to the OPD concerned about a newly developed whitish discolouration in his mouth. On examination, a white plaque-like lesion was found in his buccal mucosa, which could not be rubbed off. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Leukoplakia Explanation: The clinical scenario here points to the diagnosis of leukoplakia . Leukoplakia is defined as a white patch or plaque that cannot be rubbed off, and cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. It is a premalignant lesion and is painless/non-tender . Types : Homogenous Nodular Speckled Hairy: Associated with EBV. It is not actually hairy but appears so due to the corrugation caused by severe hyperkeratosis and acanthosis. Common in AIDS patients. Management : Biopsy to rule out carcinoma and confirm diagnosis. Stop smoking/ alcohol/ betel quid. Excision, skin grafting if needed. Regular follow-up. Isotretinoin, tocopherol, and beta-carotene. CO2 laser. Erythroplakia (Option B) is a bright red velvety plaque that cannot be characterized clinically or pathologically as any other disease. questions.question: A 45-year-old male comes to the hospital after noticing abnormal growth on the right side of his mouth. He has had a habit of smoking and chewing betel quid for more than 20 years. On further evaluation, he also gives a history of a red lesion present in the same location before the current state. Which of the following, in this case, is not a risk factor for oral carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Age above 40 years Explanation: In the above scenario, the patient's age is not a factor in increasing the risk of oral carcinoma. Oral carcinoma is one of the most common cancers in India. Risk factors: Tobacco/ pan masala (Option C) Alcohol Betel quid(areca nut, catechu, slaked lime wrapped in a piper betel leaf) (Option D) Previous exposure to radiation Chronic infections Immunosuppression Hereditary diseases like Fanconi anemia and Li-Fraumeni syndrome. Active HPV Premalignant lesions Potentially/premalignant lesions: Leukoplakia Erythroplakia (Option B) Erythroleukoplakia Proliferative verrucous leukoplakia (PVL) Oral submucous fibrosis Oral lichen planus Lupus erythematosus Epidermolysis bullosa Dyskeratosis congenita Erythtroleukoplakia, PVL, and dyskeratosis congenita carry the highest risk for malignant transformation. Out of leukoplakia, erythroplakia and erythro-leukoplakia, the erythroleukoplakia has the highest risk of malignant transformation. Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, pg: 814, 815.
